page.title: 03ARCHITECTURE DOWNDERRY
page.content: The design and structure of the buildings reflect the function and the severe environmental conditions of wind,damp and topography.The most suitable materials available are stone,slate,concrete in all its forms, asbestos,non corrosive metals and timber.These are used as economically as possible. The major settlement in the S.E.of the block contains most of the population; small numbers still live in and around the surviving farms Early buildings are of stone,locally quarried,with natural slate roofs, lacking eaves. Later, two storey stone built semi- detached houses exhibit painted stucco. From 1920 most houses were of rendered block and brickwork. Formerly these materials came from Seaton (worked sea sand) and Looe (brick,carried by barge).Now materials are imported,by road,from any source.
